faqs.question: Which improvement has the best ROI?
faqs.answer: LED bulbs typically have the fastest payback (under 1 year). Smart thermostats and insulation follow with 2-3 year payback periods.

faqs.question: How much can LED bulbs save?
faqs.answer: LED bulbs use 75% less energy than incandescent and 25% less than CFLs. A typical home can save $100-200 per year.

faqs.question: Is a smart thermostat worth it?
faqs.answer: Yes, smart thermostats typically save 10-15% on heating and cooling, paying for themselves in 1-2 years.

faqs.question: How long do solar water heaters take to pay back?
faqs.answer: Solar water heaters typically pay back in 4-8 years depending on local sun hours and electricity costs.

faqs.question: Should I improve insulation or replace the AC first?
faqs.answer: Generally, improve insulation first. Better insulation reduces the load on your AC, potentially allowing a smaller, cheaper replacement unit.

faqs.question: What is the biggest energy user in most homes?
faqs.answer: Heating and cooling typically account for 40-50% of home energy use, followed by water heating at 15-20%.

faqs.question: How can I reduce my energy consumption quickly?
faqs.answer: Quick wins include: adjusting thermostat by 2°C, using LED bulbs, unplugging unused devices, and running appliances during off-peak hours.

faqs.question: How much energy does air conditioning use?
faqs.answer: Air conditioning can use 3-5 kWh per hour of operation. Setting to 24°C instead of 20°C can save 20-30% of cooling costs.

faqs.question: Should I turn off appliances or leave them on standby?
faqs.answer: Turn them off. Standby power can account for 5-10% of your electricity bill - about 50-100 kWh per month for a typical home.

faqs.question: How often should I do an energy audit?
faqs.answer: Do a basic audit seasonally and a comprehensive audit annually. Track consumption monthly to identify unusual increases.

faqs.question: How long do solar panels last?
faqs.answer: Quality solar panels last 25-30 years. Most maintain 80% efficiency after 25 years. Warranties typically guarantee 25 years.

faqs.question: What is a good payback period?
faqs.answer: A payback period of 6-10 years is typical and considered good. After payback, you enjoy essentially free electricity.

faqs.question: How much roof space do I need?
faqs.answer: Roughly 5-7 square meters per kW of solar capacity. A 5kW system needs about 25-35 square meters of roof space.

faqs.question: Do solar panels work on cloudy days?
faqs.answer: Yes, but at reduced efficiency (10-25% of full capacity). Annual production estimates account for average weather conditions.

faqs.question: Should I get battery storage?
faqs.answer: Batteries add cost but provide energy independence and backup power. They're most valuable with time-of-use electricity rates.

faqs.question: How much waste does the average person produce?
faqs.answer: The global average is about 1.2 kg per day, but this ranges from 0.5 kg in low-income countries to over 2 kg in high-income countries.

faqs.question: What percentage of waste is food?
faqs.answer: Food waste typically makes up 30-40% of household waste. Much of this could be composted instead of landfilled.

faqs.question: Why does organic waste produce methane?
faqs.answer: Organic matter decomposing without oxygen (as in landfills) produces methane. Composting with oxygen produces CO₂, which is 25x less harmful.

faqs.question: How can I reduce my waste?
faqs.answer: Follow the 5 Rs: Refuse what you don't need, Reduce what you do need, Reuse what you can, Recycle what you can't reuse, Rot (compost) the rest.

faqs.question: What is the biggest contributor to household waste?
faqs.answer: Food and food packaging typically account for 40-50% of household waste by weight.

faqs.question: What affects solar ROI the most?
faqs.answer: Installation cost, local electricity rates, sun hours, and roof orientation have the biggest impact on ROI.

faqs.question: How accurate is the payback estimate?
faqs.answer: Estimates are within 10-15% for most installations. Actual results depend on weather patterns and electricity rate changes.

faqs.question: Should I wait for better technology?
faqs.answer: Solar technology improves slowly (1-2% per year), while electricity costs rise. Waiting usually costs more than it saves.

faqs.question: What is the typical system size for a home?
faqs.answer: Most homes need 5-10 kW systems. A 5kW system powers an average home and requires about 30-35 m² of roof space.
